instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message:
Liquid damaged.
bklt bins burnt off on the LVDS connector, replaced it, twice.

LED Driver had a burnt out pin 8, replaced it too.

Still no backlight. I'm getting ~8.5v on 3 & 4 of J8300.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: Feedback trace to ball A5 checked? <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> and PWM present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message:
Yes, I checked the trace when I replaced the LED Driver.

<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> and PWM are missing, one both boards.


[SUB]I have three of them that have come back now with all similar problems.
Could it be a bad batch of LED Drivers?[/SUB]

I'm guessing pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> shouldn't measure 0.000 in diode mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: Is there even an image?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: Definitely an image.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: Did you check the fuse?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message:
Yeh, I did.

Check it every now and then in case I blow it while working as I have done once before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: If there really is 8.5V on the backlight rail the <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> must be present as it is a simple resistor devider off that rail. Double check and don't assume anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message:
I just noticed that I am getting an unstable reading on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>

It goes from 8.59 down to about 6v then back up again. Ever now and then it seems to drop to 0v.

Any idea what that means?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: Pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>? You are measuring with an LCD connected I hope.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 23896"]Pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>? You are measuring with an LCD connected I hope.[/QUOTE]

<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>::3 = 2.843v

<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> is stable now. I measured it several times before to make sure it was fluctuating....

These three backlight boards are sending me loopy.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: Then we are back to the simple resistor divider on <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> so that must be present. <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> present too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> with a DMM is 1.46v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: Come on, I also need to know if <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> is there of course.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: It is, at 2.84v @ <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: PWM is too low. Have you done a PRAM reset? Is <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.3

I have performed an PRAM reset.

I tried putting 3v on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> to get the screen at full brightness, but nothing changed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: I have no other ideas. It is either a bad <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>, badly soldered, corroded feedback trace to ball A5. There is nothing more to these.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message:
Are bad LP8550s a thing?

The last batch (10, used 5) I bought, each one has come back with some sort of problem that looks like a backlight issue.

Another just came back with a flickering backlight....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message: Nope, never had an issue with them. Check your work and always inspect the feedback trace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight.
threads.message:
Guess that means it has to be me.
